children.heading: value

discussion.comment: Annex H states that this is part of the configuration but NTCIP 8004 states that all read-only objects are status objects. Do we need to allow for exceptions for read-only objects? In other words, is the assertion that some configuration objects can only be changed through non-SNMP methods? If so, do we need to create a third type of parameter? Or perhaps this is a special case of inter-related configuration object?

NOTE: This produces an interesting side effect. The display hint allows a machine to convert a value of 45000000 to be presented as 45.000000, but it would then display the value assigned to the UNITS clause resulting in a display of: "45.000000 microdegrees latitude" Should we change the units to degrees (but then that becomes potentially confusing when you read it)
This is redundant except for sensor errors. Do we want to keep?

All of the other location objects in this standard are in microdegrees. Do we want to keep all location objetcs in this standard in microdegrees, have a mixture of microdegrees and 1/10ths of microdegrees or change all to 1/10ths of microdegrees
Many other standards are using decimeters. Do we want to update all of our height objects?

radiationSensorLongitude INTEGER,
radiationSensorLocation DisplayString,
radiationSensorModelInformation INTEGER,
-- SENSOR READINGS
essTotalSunV4 INTEGER,
essInstantaneousTerrestrialRadiationV4 INTEGER,
essInstantaneousSolarRadiationV4 INTEGER,
essTotalRadiationV4 INTEGER}

discussion.comment: Previously the definition said W/m^2 but the <Units> clause said J/m^2. If this is an "average" I believe it should be W/m^2; if we want to report "total radiation" (i.e., a sum) J/m^2 (i.e., convertible to kWh/m^2) would be the more appropriate units. However, given that the period over which the total can be summed is configurable from 0 to 86400 seconds (1 sec to 1 day), the range on the sum would need to be much larger e.g., 0.01 to 2,800,000.00 kWh/m^2 at a minimum. Thus, I assume the intent is an average in W/m^2

discussion.comment: Needs review, what is precisely meant here. Is this intended to be a static value or dynamic (e.g., it can be effected by precipitation). Is it intended for the speed limit, prevailing speed, or some assumed speed (i.e., it can be effected by speed). Is it based on some idealized tire? Is this actually implemented by devices, and if so, is it used by agencies. It seems too vague to provide meaningful information.
In v04 this only traced to Retrieve Sensor Profile with Mobile Sources (which is deprecated and likely deleted)

discussion.comment: MIssing trace
Missing trace

Given that the text does not explicitly state that the value initializes at zero or any reset conditions, I assume that the Counter/Counter32 semantics apply - i.e., it initializes at a potentially random value and does not support resets
This object had indicated units of milliseconds, which does not seem to make sense for a "counter"
This does not conform to the semantic of a counter

Given that the text does not explicitly state that the value initializes at zero or any reset conditions, I assume that the Counter/Counter32 semantics apply - i.e., it initializes at a potentially random value and does not support resets

    • {{/unless}} {{#if (eval type "==" "un")}} {{#unless status}}

    • {{/unless}} {{#if (eval status "==" "current")}}{{#unless conformance}}
  • Missing "conformance"
    • {{/unless}}{{/if}} {{#if (or (eval status "==" "current") (eval status "==" "silent"))}} {{#if (hasInlinks "fulfil")}} {{#eachInlinkWith type="fulfil"}}{{#unless (eval status "==" "current")}}

    • {{/unless}}{{/eachInlinkWith}} {{else}} {{#unless (hasInlinks "opt_group")}}
